Today I joined Senator Orrin Hatch (R-UT), Senator Dianne Feinstein (D-CA), and Rep. Jim Sensenbrenner (R-WI) in introducing the bipartisan, bicameral Rapid DNA Act.   The bill would establish a system to enable law enforcement officials to use Rapid DNA instruments to help reduce DNA backlogs. Unlike traditional DNA analysis, which can take weeks, Rapid DNA analysis permits processing of samples in approximately 90 minutes or less.  As an Alameda County prosecutor, I learned all too well that a DNA backlog leaves crimes unsolved, leaves the public unprotected, and leaves victims crying out for justice – none of which are acceptable. DNA can be a powerful law-enforcement tool when samples are tested in a timely fashion, and this legislation will help provide that tool to police agencies across the nation, to all Americans’ benefit.

I sent this letter yesterday to more than a dozen of #CA15’s largest employers, urging them to consider the moral, economic, and security pitfalls of President Trump’s cruel and harmful #MuslimBan immigration executive order:   America is a country that always has -- and must continue to -- welcome immigrants, particularly refugees. President Trump's recent ban of persons entering the U.S. from seven majority-Muslim countries violates who we are as a welcoming, diverse country. I hope you will consider reviewing this cruel policy and how it affects our region, your workforce, and our global economy.   The congressional district I represent and in which your company does business, California's 15th, is one of the most diverse parts of the United States. It would be hard to find a large employer in our area who has not benefited from the skills of an immigrant workforce or customer base. Particularly, the East Bay is home to thousands of Muslims, many of whom immigrated -- either on visas or as refugees -- to the East Bay from a Muslim-majority country. While their backgrounds and journeys are different, most immigrants are resilient, are devoted to their new home, and work hard to provide for themselves and their family. It is this spirit of the immigrant that fuels so many companies in our area.   President Trump's ban threatens our diversity and economic productivity. If it is not reversed, our region -- and America -- will suffer cultural and economic consequences. Culturally, it will be used to sow divisions between Muslims in America and people of other faiths and backgrounds. Economically, having a ban will limit where we can draw upon for talent across the world -- not only from the countries banned, but also from people we wish to attract globally who will now fear they could be kicked out of our country because of how they worship. Ninety-six companies, including Apple, Facebook, and Uber, recently signed onto an amicus brief opposing this ban, recognizing its harmful effect on our country and our people.  Our national security is my highest priority. I worked as a prosecutor for Alameda County for seven years and now serve as the senior Democrat who oversees the Central Intelligence Agency. This ban does not make us more safe; it makes us less safe. It alienates our allies who have taken hundreds of thousands of refugees and who we depend upon for cooperation in the fight against terrorism. And worse, it motivates the enemy to inspire new terrorists to carry out attacks against the United States and our allies, under the message that we are not welcoming to Muslims. We can continue to keep our country safe with the vetting processes already in place without sacrificing our welcoming nature and the economic benefits it reaps.    It is my hope you will consider the consequences this ban has for our region and country. If you have any questions please do not hesitate to contact me.   All my best, Eric Swalwell Member of Congress

Good news: The bipartisan, bicameral Rapid DNA Act – of which I was the lead Democratic House cosponsor, to help local law enforcement use new technology to speed up justice – has been signed into law by President Donald Trump.  Traditional DNA analysis can take weeks, but Rapid DNA analysis permits processing of samples in about 90 minutes or less. The technology revolutionizes the way in which those arrested for crimes are enrolled in the criminal justice system; shortens the time required for their DNA to be linked to unsolved crimes; and speeds up innocent people’s exoneration.   The Rapid DNA Act will let local law enforcement agencies – under standards and guidelines established by the FBI – perform real-time DNA testing at the time of arrest within their own booking stations, comparing samples to profiles in the FBI’s Combined DNA Index System (CODIS).  This law’s enactment proves that, even in troubled political times, we can work together across the aisle to make Americans safer. As a former prosecutor, a son and brother of police officers, and a Judiciary Committee member, I’m excited that this new law will help law enforcement agencies across the nation use a more powerful tool to protect and serve our communities, to clear the innocent, and to attain justice for victims.

I am an original co-sponsor of H.R. 3947, the Automatic Gunfire Prevention Act, introduced yesterday by Congressman David Cicilline, D-RI.  The bill would prohibit sale of “bump stocks,” a kind of accessory for semi-automatic rifles. A bump stock lets the shooter fire at a rate of 400 to 800 rounds per minute, replicating the rate of fire of a fully automatic weapon that propels multiple bullets with a single trigger pull.   Stephen Paddock, who massacred dozens last Sunday in Las Vegas, reportedly used bump stocks. It’s amazing to me that these devices – clearly intended to skirt our laws against fully automatic weapons – were ever allowed on the market, but banning them now would be a good first step.   Next, let’s listen to the overwhelming majority of Americans who want truly universal background checks for gun purchases, and let’s ban high-capacity magazines that make it easier to kill more people faster.
